title: Krishen Khanna
summary: Krishen Khanna is a distinguished Indian painter, self-taught, renowned for his abstracted figurative artworks that capture Indian street scenes, idioms, and human values. A former banker who transitioned to art full-time in 1961, he was a member of the influential Progressive Artists' Group. His notable series include 'Truckwallahs' and 'Bandwallahs,' alongside works exploring Christian themes. Khanna's significant contributions to art have been recognized with prestigious awards such as the Rockefeller Fellowship (1962), Padma Shri (1990), and Padma Bhushan (2011). He currently lives and works in New Delhi.

timeline: 1925: Born on 5 July in Lyallpur (now Faisalabad, Pakistan).
1930: His father returned from England with copies of da Vinci's artworks, inspiring young Krishen.
1938: Received the Rudyard Kipling Scholarship and studied art for the first time at Imperial Service College in England.
1942: Passed the Oxford and Cambridge School of Certificate with a subject in arts.
1946: Enrolled in Sheikh Ahmed's studio to study drawing.
1961: Quit his banking job at Grindlay's Bank to become a full-time artist.
